channel.title: Comments on: Using VS.NET 2005 SP1 with SQL Server 2008 connectivity
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Not where I work ðŸ™‚

We generally use the latest .NET version available, since we also all have MSDN VS 2008 is no problem either

But yeah upgrading Databases is another story…we still have servers on 2000..but After July 1st sometime (start of new fiscal year) they will be upgraded to 2008

we will actually upgrade one server to 2008 already on Monday 9AM (according to the ticket)

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: Which is more than likely true for the majority of product based companies. upgrades and new technology cost money and IT is nothing more than a spending house when you sell a widget. People just don't upgrade because they release a new version in that type of environment. You know that
item.content:encoded: Which is more than likely true for the majority of product based companies. upgrades and new technology cost money and IT is nothing more than a spending house when you sell a widget. People just don’t upgrade because they release a new version in that type of environment. You know that

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I see, you don't develop for .NET 3.5 so no fancy var keywords for you<br /> That makes sense then....for you
item.content:encoded:
I see, you don’t develop for .NET 3.5 so no fancy var keywords for you
That makes sense then….for you

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
>>Can you use LINQ and .NET 3.5 stuff in VS 2005?

Absolutely no need. Until the business or the development team find a need there is no reason.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
>>Why install VS 2008? ðŸ˜‰

Can you use LINQ and .NET 3.5 stuff in VS 2005?

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
>>Also why do you think VS 2005 is better than VS 2008

I don’t. Bad use of words up there. 2005 is stable and a very good development tool IMO. I haven’t had a problem with it in years. If it works I don’t try to break it ðŸ˜‰

>>Why wouldn’t you install VS 2008? You can still target .NET 2.0 if you need to

Yes but I can ask the same question. Why install VS 2008? ðŸ˜‰

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Why wouldn’t you install VS 2008? You can still target .NET 2.0 if you need to

Also why do you think VS 2005 is better than VS 2008? Are there any specific things that you can think off?
